sn35.74:1.2: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, and said to him,
sn35.74:1.3: “Sir, in such and such a monastery there’s a mendicant who is junior and not well-known. He’s sick, suffering, gravely ill.
sn35.74:1.4: Please go to him out of sympathy.”
sn35.74:2.1: When the Buddha heard that the mendicant was junior and ill, understanding that he was not well-known, he went to him.
sn35.74:2.2: That mendicant saw the Buddha coming off in the distance
sn35.74:2.3: and tried to rise on his cot.
sn35.74:2.4: The Buddha said to that monk,
sn35.74:2.5: “It’s all right, mendicant, don’t get up.
sn35.74:2.6: There are some seats spread out, I will sit there.”
sn35.74:2.7: He sat on the seat spread out
sn35.74:2.9: “I hope you’re keeping well, mendicant; I hope you’re all right. I hope that your pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.”
sn35.74:3.1: “Sir, I’m not keeping well, I’m not getting by. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is evident, not its fading.”
sn35.74:4.1: “I hope you don’t have any remorse or regret?”
sn35.74:5.1: “Indeed, sir, I have no little remorse and regret.”
sn35.74:6.1: “I hope you have no reason to blame yourself when it comes to ethical conduct?”
sn35.74:7.1: “No sir, I have no reason to blame myself when it comes to ethical conduct.”
sn35.74:8.1: “In that case, mendicant, why do you have remorse and regret?”
sn35.74:9.1: “Because I understand that the Buddha has not taught the Dhamma merely for the sake of ethical purity.”
sn35.74:10.1: “If that is so, what then do you understand to be the purpose of teaching the Dhamma?”
sn35.74:11.1: “I understand that the Buddha has taught the Dhamma for the purpose of the fading away of greed.”
sn35.74:12.2: It’s good that you understand that I’ve taught the Dhamma for the purpose of the fading away of greed.
sn35.74:12.3: For that is indeed the purpose.
sn35.74:12.5: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”
sn35.74:16.1: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn35.74:18.1: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:
sn35.74:18.2: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn35.74:20.1: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
sn35.74:20.2: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
sn35.74:20.3: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended … there is nothing further for this place.’”
sn35.74:21.1: That is what the Buddha said.
sn35.74:21.2: Satisfied, that mendicant approved what the Buddha said.
sn35.74:21.3: And while this discourse was being spoken, the stainless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma arose in that mendicant:
sn35.74:21.4: “Everything that has a beginning has an end.”
